_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ASRC RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

At American Synthetic Rubber Corporation, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

      *  A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP)   
          regulation
      *  A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental
          chemical releases
       *  An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
       *  A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
       *  An overview of our emergency response program
       *  An overview of planned improvements at our facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases
           from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment
       *  The certifications that EPA's RMP rule requires us to provide
       *  The detailed information (called data elements) about our risk management program

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES


American Synthetic Rubber Corporation is located on a 60.5 acre site in the Southwest section of Jefferson County, Kentucky within the industrial area known as Rubbertown.  Manufacturing operations are conducted on a seven day continuous basis.  We employ approximately 380 individuals who work nominal shift hours of 7:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m., 3:00 p.m. - 11:00 p.m., or 11:00 p.m. - 7:00 a.m.  Approximately 260 employees are on site weekdays between the hours of 7:00

a.m. and 3:00 p.m.  Approximately 47 employees operate the plant at all other times.

Product lines include solution polybutadiene (BR) and solution styrene butadiene (SSBR)  rubbers, which are utilized primarily in the manufacturing of automobile tires, and a polybutadiene - acrylonitrile - acrylic acid (PBAN) terpolymer which is utilized as a component in the manufacturing of solid rocket propellants.  

Bulk raw materials are received via tank car and tank truck. Non - bulk raw material receipts (drum / carton commodities) are generally received via common carrier.  Facilities for receiving and storage of the more volatile process materials are located outdoors in areas as remote as practical from the main plant processes.  These installations are typically protected and provided with a means of secondary containment (e.g. dikes) in order to minimize hazards resulting from spillage.  The physical transfer of raw materials from transport container to storage and on to the various processing units is accomplished by means of pumps and / or inert gas pressure.

POLYBUTADIENE AND SOLUTION SBR, reaction products of butadiene and butadiene / styrene respectively, are manufactured in a continuous polymerization process utilizing toluene as a diluent.  Organometallic catalysts are added to initiate the reaction and carry it to the desired level of conversion.  The resulting polymer solution is then pumped through a series of flash distillation units to recover the unreacted butadiene and a significant portion of the solvent, leaving a more viscous solution.

The majority of the remaining solvent is then separated (stripped) from the polymer using a steam distillation process.  This occurs by bringing the polymerized rubber into contact with hot water and steam.  Stripped vapors arising form this operation are condensed and recovered for reuse.  The remaining crumb water slurry is then dewatered, dried, baled, containerized and warehoused. 

PBAN, a reaction product of bu

tadiene / acrylonitrile / acrylic acid, is a batch process.  An emulsifying agent or soap is utilized to facilitate the dispersion of the ingredients in a water medium and a catalyst added to initiate the reaction and accelerate it to completion.  The polymerized emulsion is commonly referred to as latex.  Unreacted compounds are either recovered and returned to the supplier or discharged to the wastewater treatment plant.  The latex is coagulated by the addition of brine and subsequently dried.  Finished product is then transferred to hold tanks pending laboratory analysis and on to storage.

IN OUR PROCESSES, we use the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant off site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

     Toxics:

          Acrylonitrile.   We maintain an on site inventory of approximately 65,000 lbs of acrylonitrile.  This
          chemical is one of the reactants used in the manufacturing of PBAN polymer.   Our maximum storage
          capacity is approximately 203,000 lbs.

          Ammonia.    We maintain an on site inventory of approximately 20,000 lbs of anhydrous ammonia.
          Ammonia is used solely as a refrigerant in various parts of our manufacturing process.  Our
          maximum storage capacity is approximately 23,000 lbs.

          Titanium Tetrachloride.   We maintain an on site inventory of approximately 10,000 lbs of titanium
          tetrachloride.  This material is used as a catalyst in the manufacture of  polybutadiene and solution
          SBR rubber.  It is delivered and stored in 1,150 lb DOT shipping containers until it is introduced into
          our processes.   We keep approximately 9 full containers on site.  At various times we have stored
          a maximum of 18 containers on site.

     Flammables:

          1,3-Butadiene.   We maintain an on site inventory of approximately 4,000,000 lbs of butadiene.  This
          chemical is the primar

y raw material used in the manufacturing of our products.  Our maximum
          storage capacity is approximately 8,100,000 lbs.

          Hydrogen.   We maintain an on site inventory of approximately 1,400 lbs of liquid hydrogen.    Our
          maximum storage capacity is 2,750 lbs.

Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts allow us to effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.

KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS

EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case release scenario(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario.  We believe the actions we have taken, and continue to be involved with, make the actual worst-case scenarios very unlikely to happen.

     Worst-case Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Toxic Chemicals

          Ammonia.   The contents of a 1,500 gallon outdoor storage tank are assumed to be spilled with 3.4
          mph winds, 77 deg F temperature and 50% relative humidity (stability class F) weather conditions
          prevailing.  This release results in a scenario circle which extends several blocks from the plant.
          Within the circle are homes, commercial and industrial facilities and schools.  This tank is located
          inside a concrete dike and is protected from passing vehicular traffic by a steel guard rail.

     Alternative Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Toxic Chemicals

           Acrylonitrile.   The contents of a tank truck are assumed to be spilled with 6.7 mph winds, 77 deg F
           temperature and 50% relative humidity (stability class D) weather conditions prevailing.  This
           release results in a scenario circle which extends a short distance beyo

nd the plant's property line.
           Within the circle are homes and industrial facilities.  These tank trucks are unloaded inside a
           concrete dike which is protected from fire by an automatically activated aqueous fire fighting foam
           (AFFF) deluge system.  Standard operating procedures require our Tankfarm operator to attend and
           monitor the unloading operation.  The unloading operation is also monitored remotely via closed
           circuit TV at the plant's central process control building.

           Ammonia.   Ammonia vapor from a compressor suction line knockout tank is assumed to be released
           through a safety relief valve with 6.7 mph winds, 77 deg F temperature and 50% relative humidity
           (stability class D) weather conditions prevailing.  This release results in a scenario circle which
           extends a short distance beyond the plant's property line.  Within the circle are homes and industrial
           facilities.

           Titanium Tetrachloride.   The contents of a 1,150 lb DOT shipping container are assumed to be
           spilled through an uncoupled 1-inch unloading hose with 6.7 mph winds, 77 deg F temperature and
           50% relative humidity (stability class D) weather conditions prevailing.  This release results in a
           scenario circle which extends just barely beyond the plant's property line. Within the circle are
           industrial facilities.  This container is located over a concrete dike to contain spills and is monitored
           continuously by closed circuit TV at the plant's central process control building.

      Worst-case Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

           1,3-Butadiene.   The contents of a 635,000 gallon outdoor storage tank are assumed to be spilled
           with 3.4 mph winds, 77 deg F temperature and 50% relative humidity (stability class F) weather
           conditions prevailing.  This release results in a scenario cir

cle which extends several blocks from
           the plant.  Within the circle are homes, commercial and industrial facilities and schools.  This tank is
           located inside an earthen dike and is protected from fire by an automatically activated water deluge
           system.  This area is also equipped with combustible gas detectors for the detection of butadiene
           vapors.  These detectors alarm in the plant's security office.

     Alternative Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

           1,3-Butadiene.   The contents of a tank car are assumed to be spilled through an uncoupled 2-inch
           unloading hose with 6.7 mph winds, 77 deg F temperature and 50% relative humidity (stability class
           D) weather conditions prevailing.  This release results in a scenario circle which extends a short
           distance from the plant.  Within the circle are homes and industrial facilities.  This tank car unloading
           facility is protected by a manually activated water deluge system.  Also, in accordance with DOT
           regulations, our Tankfarm operator continuously monitors the unloading of these tank cars.  This
           facility is also continuously monitored remotely via closed circuit TV from the plant's central process
           control building and is equipped with combustible gas detectors for the detection of butadiene
           vapors.  These detectors alarm in the plant's security office.

We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:

      *  Process safety information
      *  Process hazard analysis

*  Operating procedures
      *  Training
      *  Mechanical integrity
      *  Management of change
      *  Pre-startup review
      *  Compliance audits
      *  Incident investigation
      *  Employee participation
      *  Hot work permit
      *  Contractor evaluation and screening

As part of our prevention efforts, we have implemented the following chemical-specific prevention steps:

      *  Sealless 1,3-butadiene pumps
      *  Sealless acrylonitrile pumps
      *  1,3-Butadiene decontamination system
      *  Removed unused ammonia equipment and piping from service
      *  Acrylonitrile area detection system (Baseline gas chromatograph)
      *  Collect and flare vented 1,3-butadiene vapors
      *  Collect and flare vented titanium tetrachloride vapors
      *  Collect vented acrylonitrile vapors in activated carbon canisters
      *  Secondary containment for all vessels storing covered chemicals
      *  Combustible gas detection instrumentation for 1,3-butadiene
      *  Foam deluge system to protect acrylonitrile unloading station
      *  Fire-safe valves beneath 1,3-butadiene storage tanks
      *  Certification program for training employees
      *  Leak detection and repair program (LDAR) for 1,3-butadiene piping
      *  Community disaster alarm system
      *  Provided schools within our scenario circles with communications equipment to monitor
          the local fire department and emergency responders

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

We keep records for significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical re

leases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

We have had only one off site release of a covered chemical in the past five years.  On Wednesday, November 25, 1998, approximately 3,500 lbs of anhydrous ammonia was vented to the atmosphere.  This happened when the plant sustained a complete electrical power outage as a result of a lightning strike.

We have conducted a formal incident investigation to identify and correct the root causes of the events leading to this ammonia release.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the community emergency response plan.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The following is a list of improvements that we are planning to implement at our facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

      *  Chemical response training for emergency response personnel
      *  ISO 14000 program certification
      *  Containment system for ammonia vapor vented from relief valves
      *  Protection against dry running damage for 1,3-butadiene sealless pumps
      *  Upgrade 1,3-butadiene vent header system
      *  Upgrade (higher pressure rating) BR Concentration piping
      *  Modernize process control instrumentation
      *  Implement process hazard analysis recommendations
      *  Implement mechanical integrity recommendations
      *  Maintain the community disaster alarm system in a state of readiness
